ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: I found this course useful for me to sharpen my definition of what defines a "land use practitioner". I had been exposed to many of the concepts before but the land use planning tools used to address these problems provided a new framing for me.
The class is SO broad that I didn't feel as though I learned too much of anything. Though it's a good primer and for one credit I guess I shouldn't expect that much.
Everything could have moved faster insofar as the classes could have jumped right into more advanced applications of many notions explored and introduced.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The class discussion which helped illuminate more of the complexity within some of the general concepts presented.
John Nolan is such a nice, friendly, knowledgable, and approachable professor.

Professor Nolon covers a little bit of everything, from the basics of land use to the latest trends in sustainable development. He is insightful, engages with the classroom, and planned a great field trip this semester!
The guest speakers offered good insight into their fields of expertise. Prof. Nolon tied everything else together.
I enjoyed the myriad of experience the different speakers brought in to give an overview of the planning and zoning challenges in US.
Guest speakers from a variety of backgrounds; all had interesting insights about land use planning.
The diversity of speakers and perspectives. Also the breadth of topics and strategies covered.

Professor Nolon is clearly speaking from a wealth of experience and thoughtful reflection on land use topics. He's distilled the issues into helpful pieces, and the lectures were well-organized to that end. It was a perfect survey class.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: It would have been nice to have a group assignment because I felt as though I didn't get to interact with any of the other students, though I think we all had similar interests.

This course is understandably focused on domestic land use, but it would be good to include a few international case studies. Also, students could be assigned to do a presentation for the last class instead of writing a final paper, so that we have an opportunity to interact more and learn from each other. This class is a one hour seminar, so there is little time to do so during class.
I thought that we could have more time for the lectures.
It may be better if the course is longer, to allow more time for questions.
More depth, less introductory groundwork -- teach to the top of the class and everyone else will follow along and ask questions in order to do so!
I didn't feel like there was particularly good incentive to keep up with the readings. The readings were, though, quality and appropriate.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: This is definitely the foundation for all other land use and planning courses at F&ES. The topics we covered in class are integral to understanding sustainable land use planning and development.

Excellent introduction to other courses available and a general mode of accomplishing work I am interested in, but that I would not otherwise have sought out immediately -- especially with regard to planning/design work and also law.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Interested in the field of land use planning and had never formally studied it in an academic setting.
I'm considering getting into land use planning (and doing the specialization) and I thought it would give me a good intro... it did!
I came to F&ES to supplement my anticipated land use law career with courses in land use planning and sustainable development.
To gain an understanding of how land use planning is being done in the States.
To determine how much further in this mode of working/thinking I want to venture. To seek out effective models and precedent that may be transplanted for my own causes and professional work.
I took this course to keep my knowledge of land use issues fresh, and to understand better how environmental issues play a role in land use.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: yes
Yes for a one-credit course
Yes!
Yes, Professor Nolon never fails to clearly explain even the most difficult to grasp concepts in land use.
On average, yes.
Yes-- but it could have been more-- and especially were I not going to enroll in further related coursework.
I learned exactly what I had hoped to and more. Seeing the environmental issues that need to be considered for land use planning was helpful.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: It's really interesting for planners.
Be prepared to contribute to class discussion in order to get the most out of the course.
Great for generating an understanding of land use procedures, and tools to employ when working with municipalities or other organizations concerned with land use strategies.
The seminar is well worth taking- it is only one hour per week but you learn so much!

If you think you may be interested in issues of land use planning, law, or design, this course is an excellent and low-effort introduction. After this course, you should have a much better idea of whether or not topics of land use is for you, and will have a great opportunity to interact with related faculty throughout the university (and beyond due to Professor Nolon's connections with Pace Law School).
This is a lecture-style seminar.
Just do it -- having different types of smart people explain things to you for an hour once a week has never hurt anyone and inspired many.

Quite simply, if you're interested in land use at all, take this class. It's a perfect survey class of relevant issues, and it can help you discover whether land use is a topic you wish to pursue further.
